awd_titl_txt: RUI: Sortase-Mediated Ligations for Probing Binding Mechanisms of Large Disordered Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
The functions of most cellular proteins are understood to depend on their shape or structure. Many proteins, however, include parts where the structure is not well defined. The shape and thus the functions of these intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) of proteins are difficult study. With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is supporting the research of Dr. John Antos and Dr. Sergey Smirnov from Western Washington University to develop experimental methods to study the structures of IDRs. The research team is using use a splicing enzyme (sortase) to insert specific chemical tags into proteins that allow their shapes and changes to their shapes to be monitored by Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy.  This project applies these methods to determine the key functional properties of dematin, a protein with a large IRD that helps control red blood cell shape and function. Results from these studies set the stage to study many types of IDRs in proteins that are prevalent across multiple kingdoms of life. The project prepares the next generation of scientists by training participating undergraduate and Masters level graduate students in state-of-the-art methods for analyzing protein structure and function. The project provides research opportunities to engage and attract underrepresented groups and high school students into the natural sciences. In addition, Drs. Antos and Smirnov incorporate authentic research experiences into Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) for biochemistry courses. 

Approximately one-third of eukaryotic proteins contain within their polypeptide sequences sizable intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs), which are critical for a variety of cellular functions. Many of these IDRs are large (hundreds of residues), which makes the site-specific study of these dynamic protein segments and their binding interfaces technically challenging. For example, the application of NMR, one of the preferred methods for studying IDRs, is hampered by severe spectral overlap of resonances originating from large IDRs. Similarly, the targeted insertion of functional labels such as spectroscopic reporters or post-translational modifications is often impossible due to competing labeling of multiple identical sites in extended IDR sequences. This project addresses such problems via robust and efficient site-specific sortase-mediated ligation strategies tuned for large IDR-containing substrates. This includes the development of guidelines for the use of site-specific ligation strategies in the context of large IDR-containing protein substrates. The set of methods developed lead to the generation of derivatives of the erythrocyte-controlling protein dematin segmentally labeled with NMR-active isotopes (15N and 13C). Such derivatives enable characterization of a crucial regulatory intramolecular binding interface involving the large, 315-residue IDR that is central for dematin function and regulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Approximately one-third of eukaryotic proteins contain large segments that do not possess a single, well-defined three-dimensional shape. These segments are referred to as intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs), and they are responsible for a variety of critical biological functions. Many of these IDRs are also large (involving hundreds of amino acids) which makes the study of these dynamic protein segments experimentally challenging. To address these difficulties, this award has supported studies on the development of new protein engineering techniques to assist with the characterization of proteins with disordered segments. Specifically, this work has explored the optimization of an enzyme-catalyzed approach for building novel derivatives of IDR-containing proteins that are amenable to the common protein characterization technique nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). 

The experimental work of this project has involved two major aims. In the first, we have optimized the use of the enzyme sortase for ligating together building blocks inspired by authentic IDR sequences. As part of this, we have developed a novel software tool (SLIDRs) that allows users to identify potential sortase ligation sites within IDRs that can be accessed with only minimal changes to the native protein sequence. This tool was then used to develop a panel of model sortase ligation partners based on known IDR-containing proteins to assess the impact of different amino acids immediately preceding the standard sortase ligation site motif (LPXTG). Groups of amino acids in this position were found to have a significant impact on the success of the corresponding sortase ligation reaction, with certain patterns both inhibiting and accelerating ligation. In instances where sortase ligation was less successful, we developed a practical workaround in which additional flexible glycine residues were inserted to rescue reactivity. In addition, we conducted an evaluation of a novel sequence motif that was found to accelerate sortase ligation. In a series of model studies, we demonstrated that this linker sequence outperformed standard sortase ligation linkers for the installation of useful protein modifications such as fluorescent tags. In a second more applied aim of this project, we utilized the sortase ligation approach to generate derivatives of the protein dematin. Dematin is important for the maintenance of red blood cell shape, and notably possesses a large IDR (315 amino acids). It has been hypothesized that the function of dematin is controlled through an interaction between its large IDR segment and a smaller folded region referred to as the headpiece. To begin to probe this interaction, we used sortase ligations to link fragments of the IDR to the headpiece wherein different portions were enriched in 15N isotopes. This, in turn, allowed for analysis of the protein samples using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). While analysis of these datasets will continue beyond the scope of this project, these studies have established the feasibility of using sortase ligations for building novel derivatives of IDR-containing proteins. More broadly, this project has also provided new insights into the continued development of sortase ligation as a general biomolecular engineering method. 

With the respect to broader impacts, this project has supported the training of both undergraduate and Masters-level graduate students (13 undergraduates and 5 Masters). These students have been involved in all experimental aspects of this project and have also presented their work at public venues as both posters and oral presentations. Students have also been co-authors on one publication, with additional student co-authors on at least two additional manuscripts in preparation. As another facet of broader impacts, protein samples from this project have also inspired the development of new experiences in an upper division biochemistry lab course taught by co-PI Smirnov at Western Washington University. Specifically, dematin-inspired samples and sortase ligation reactions have been utilized as instructional tools in five separate sections of this course, enrolling a total of 73 undergraduates.
